items.content_html: I‚Äôm happy today feels like a Thursday because all day yesterday felt like a Sunday.
It is too hot and muggy to do much of anything today. My family‚Äôs trip to the beach became a trip to lunch and then back home again.
App review and package delivery are on schedule today despite the holiday. I‚Äôm not upset, but it is unexpected.
These Master & Dynamic MH40 headphones are something special: premium materials, crystal clear sound, wide soundstage, and a unique bump in the bass range that I like more than I thought I would.
Were there scads of newspaper articles published I n 1935 about the file of radio (the day‚Äôs mass media) in the rise of fascism?
I suppose I will watch the Red Sox/Yankees series from the weekend, where the Yanks absolutely destroyed the Red Sox, but I really don‚Äôt want to.
I was finally smart enough today to bring the magnetic induction burner we never use outside to make pasta while I grilled ribeye and zucchini in the 95¬∞ heat.
I‚Äôm trying to get back on the MyFitnessPal horse today. I haven‚Äôt logged my food in six months and the results are really bad.
I finally got to see ‚ÄúA Quiet Place‚Äù this evening. What a excellent film! It is taut, suspenseful, and scary as hell.

My kids love the public library. My family had a nice trip there to get out of the heat today. It‚Äôs exciting now that my daughter is learning how to read. My son has enjoyed thumbing through books since he could sit up. Meanwhile, I only read on my iPad these days.

I would subscribe to Apple Music + News + TV for $149/year (or a little more for a family plan), but I‚Äôm a sucker for Apple products and services anyway. I would be a Texture subscriber today if their app experience wasn‚Äôt (in my opinion) terrible.

I think I will give Peter Davison-Reiber ‚Äòs Fantastically Good Event Parser for Drafts 5 a try. Adding calendar entries with natural language without going through Fantastical or Calendars 5 sounds great to me.
The mail I definitely don‚Äôt need to open right away is always convening labeled for me. They could work on the wording, though.
This inexpensive little device works just fine for microwave popcorn. It amazes me that we used that awful bagged stuff for years.

items.title: As Kennedy Retires, the Supreme Court‚Äôs Attack on Labor Unions Is a Sign of Things to Come
items.content_html:
No kidding, The New Yorker, no kidding:

For years, conservatives complained about activist liberal judges making it up as they went along. Today, they are the activists. Under the guise of ‚Äúoriginalism,‚Äù they are rewriting the nation‚Äôs laws to further the reactionary political agenda of the Republican Party and its biggest donors.

Note the scare quotes around ‚Äúoriginalism‚Äù. It, like all the other -ism words we throw around‚Äîconservatism, liberalism, socialism‚Äî is completely devoid of meaning.

I have not been blogging as much recently because I have been disturbed so much by the onslaught of surprising and disturbing headlines here in the US. I honestly don‚Äôt know what to say anymore. I find joy in my family (they are great!!!) and almost nowhere else right now.
My clever, well-written new app currently does everything it‚Äôs supposed to do‚Ä¶except the main thing it‚Äôs supposed to do. I guess I‚Äôve got some debugging and re-engineering to do!

items.title: Tower 3.0's release and new pricing model
items.content_html:
I have been beta testing Tower 3.0, which is a very nice Git GUI client, for the past few months. The team behind it have just announced that the version 3.0 is complete. I was ready last week to purchase the software at its old price, which would be a one-time purchase of $79, but Tower has also announced that it is moving to subscription pricing for version 3.

Switching from paid-up-front to subscription-based is somewhat controversial. I, for one, am all for software subscriptions, so I support the developers‚Äô decision. However, their decision has signaled that Tower is not for me. Even with the generous 50% discount for the first year that they have offered me, as a beta tester, the developers have priced me out of their product. For a professional, making a living from their software, the subscription cost for an important workplace tool is merely a drop in the bucket. But for me, a hobbyist developer who charges for my apps to cover my costs, I don‚Äôt make nearly enough money from my apps to justify paying more than a couple dollars per month for a Git client.

Git‚Äôs command line tools and Atlassian‚Äôs SourceTree client are free to use. I will be back to using SourceTree‚Äîwhich which is free, full-featured, but not as well polished as Tower‚Äîshortly. Thanks to the Tower team for allowing me to beta test their software. I wish them the best of luck.
I have learned a heck of a lot about clean iOS app architecture from Dave Delong‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Better MVC‚Äù series.
I‚Äôm starting a new thing at work today. It will be an uphill climb for a little while, I think.
Today I took the time to delight in the company of my wife and children. We went to the shore, which is nearby, and shared a wonderful and simple day.

I‚Äôm thinking of trading in my V-Moda Crossfade 2‚Äôs plus $100 to upgrade to thier Codex edition, which are the same headphones plus AAC and aptX support over Bluetooth. The better codecs will make them useful longer, like when the Lightning port goes away.

My wife and I are going to see ‚ÄúIn the Heights‚Äù tomorrow night, and I am super-psyched. If you only know of Lin-Manuel Miranda‚Äôs ‚ÄúHamilton‚Äù, you would do well to listen to his other Best Musical Tony Award winner.
The Last of the Tiger Parents is a lovely article that provides a different, more introspective dimension to this week‚Äôs uproar about racial bias at elite schools in New York City and Harvard.

I found the article published last week that links to my iOS to-do app, SwiftoDo, my old todo.txt Mac client (buy SwiftoDo Desktop instead) and to my plaintext productivity website as well: Every To-Do List App Sucks, Switch To todo.txt Instead üòÄ
